results.title: Cal
results.creator_credit: Enigma Productions, Stuart Craig, David Puttnam and Pat O'Connor
results.brief_description: Cal, played by John Lynch in a very impressive film debut, is an unemployed 19 year-old Catholic who is unwillingly drawn into the dangerous and violent world of the IRA, becoming an accomplice in the murder of a Protestant policeman. When he gets a job on the lonely farm where the dead man’s widow Marcella, played flawlessly by Helen Mirren, lives with her in-laws, Cal finds himself drawn to her. It is the start of a passionate affair between the guilt-ridden youth and the unhappy woman, a moving romance that ultimately ends in tragedy. This compelling story gains considerably in its dramatic impact from the superbly realized background of the bitter sectarian violence in Northern Ireland. Based on the original novel by Bernard MacLaverty and featuring the beautifully haunting music of Mark Knopfler (Dire Straits).

results.title: Cakes: basic techniques
results.brief_description: Illustrates and explains the step by step procedures for baking a variety of cakes from ‘scratch’. Shows shortened cake, one-pan mixing, angel food cake, cream cheese frosting, seven minute frosting anf fruit glaze.

results.title: Cairo: as told by Youssef Chahine
results.creator_credit: Misr International Films, Miroirs, Mustapha Abdel Aziz and Youssef Chahine
results.brief_description: Personal documentary essay on the city of Cairo by renowned Egyptian filmmaker Youssef Chahine. Director of over forty films, Chahine is renowned for his diverse styles and often controversial subject matter. “Cairo as told by Youssef Chahine” began as a commission by French TV for the news series Envoye Special. Using his unique sense of artistic digression, Chahine begins the film by poking fun at conventional travelogue imagery of Cairo, before going on to explore, from a deeply personal perspective, the contemporary political, religious and social life of the city he loves. The film was banned in Egypt for showing too much dirt.

results.title: Cairo station = Bab el hadid
results.brief_description: Renowned Egyptian director Youssef Chahine established his international reputation with “Cairo Station” after it screened at the Berlin Film Festival. Focusing on a group of marginalised luggage carriers and soft-drink sellers who live in abandoned traincars, Chahine posits Cairo’s main railroad station as a microcosm of Egyptian society. A crippled newspaper dealer (played powerfully by Chahine himself), falls in love with a beautiful but indifferent lemonade seller who is engaged to the muscular and virile leader of the luggage-carriers. Swept away by his obsessive desire, the crippled man kidnaps the object of his passion, with terrible consequences. Into this story of doomed sexual obsession amongst a shadowy underclass, Chahine weaves glaring economic disparity, union activity, and other politically charged motifs. The work of Fritz Lang and the genres of film-noir and neo-realism are often cited as influences on the film. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Caged fury (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Adventure parade”.
WARNING: CONTAINS VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES Man’s capture and training of wild African beasts. The animals are seen in their native surroundings and the continual struggle for survival is depicted in scenes of fighting and killing. Shows the animals being trapped and shipped abroad, and the training methods through which they gradually adapt themselves to a new life.
